title.rendered: Sitting at the Last Passover and First Communion with Christ, Part 2 By Evangelist Phil Sessa <

content.rendered:
Good morning,

If you recall in Genesis 22, when Abraham would attempt to sacrifice his son Isaac on the altar there are striking parallels to the crucifixion of Christ.

Isaac would have walked by the will of his father to the place of sacrifice. The wood would be carried to the place of sacrifice. Isaac was laid on the place that he would be slain by the father, and the piecing object (a knife in this account) was going to be thrust into Abraham’s son by the father. In this midst of all of this Isaac would ask a poignant and crucial question. “Look, the fire and the wood, but where is the lamb for a burnt offering?” And Abraham said, “My son, God will provide for Himself the lamb for a burnt offering (7-8).” Abraham believed that if he killed his most precious treasure, his son, that God would raise him from the dead. The writer of Hebrew in chapter 11 magnifies this reality:17By faith Abraham, when he was tested, offered up Isaac, and he who had received the promises offered up his only begotten son, 18 of whom it was said, “In Isaac your seed shall be called,” 19 concluding that God was able to raise him up, even from the dead, from which he also received him in a figurative sense (7 – 19).The day came on Friday when God Himself would choose His chosen Lamb and would offer Him up as a sacrifice, a substitute for sinner and He would pour out his perfect wrath on Christ, the innocent substitute.MacArthur shares again, “It is Thursday night of Passover week. Passover begins with this Thursday night, followed with seven days of the unleavened bread feast which also commemorated the exodus out of Egypt. Millennia have gone by, waiting for an adequate sacrifice. Millennia have gone by with people’s hearts hoping and hoping and hoping but never being satisfied that a true and final sacrifice had come. But one more day, a few more hours on Friday at exactly the hours of slaughter between three and six when all the Passover lambs had to be killed, the Lamb of God would die in that same period of time”.
The parallels between the requirements of the Torah for the choosing of a Lamb and the details of Christ’s Passion Week are amazing when realized. R.C. Shares in his article Meeting Jesus at an Old Testament Feast, “The Torah required selected lambs to be put on display for four days (Exodus 12:3 – 6) to verify that they were without blemish. Jesus followed the triumphal entry, presented Himself in the temple for that exact period, for that exact perfect. He submitted Himself testing by the Pharisees, Herodians, Sadducees, and scribes (Mark 12:3)”You may make an assumption that there were those in cahoots that took Christ’s life from Him. Yet one thing is sure it was not the Jewish leaders that took his life ultimately though they wanted him killed for His allegedly blasphemy, their jealousy, and their rage as he upset their economic standings (recall His flipping the tables over in the outer court of the Temple). The Romans were the only ones that could administer the death penalty, but it was not the Romans that actually killed the Savior. No, none of these groups took His life, but rather He freely laid it down as he proclaimed because Pilate. He willingly had His life out of obedience to God the Father, and to glorify the Father, as God the Son would in agreement with the Father be slain for the Glory of God. Christ knew that He would die, by what means, and when, and orchestrated everything to lead to His own death. MacArthur states, “The cross loomed in front of him every day of his conscious life. He would die on the Passover day in the middle of the afternoon on a Friday in A.D. 30 in the month of Nissan on the fourteenth day as God’s Passover Lamb. He would die at the very same hour Passover lambs by the tens of thousands were being slaughtered. He knew every detail about His coming death.”Christ was a Prophet and message, priest and sacrifice, and King and the glory with full authority. The sacrifice had to be offered by a priest, but Christ was both the Priest after the order of Melchizedek, and he was the sacrifice simultaneously.Who was Christ thinking about on the cross? There is a song that states concerning the crucifixion, “and you thought of me above all” Christ the Son was thinking about the glory of God the Father above all, as can be realized in all His statements made while on the cross. Father forgive them they know not what they do, Father why has thou forsaken Me, Father into your hands I commit my spirit.” Christ lived under the Law and was the only one that kept the Law, unlike you and I that are Law breakers (transgressors of His Ten Commandments). God Commands all men [humanity] everywhere to repent and put their trust in Christ [the same way one would trust in a parachute when jumping out of a plane]. Why, because He will judge the world in righteousness, and if you stand before the Lord in your own righteousness you will perish on the Day of Judgment. However, if you stand in the righteousness of Christ you will be judged as innocent on that Day.God treats Christ as if He lived our wretched sinful lives, and treats only those in Christ, as if they lived the life of Christ (perfect, clean and glorifying God before His face). All will die and stand before the Lord. Is Christ your greatest and most prized treasure, and would those closest to you concede that He is?. Would your parents, spouse, closest friends, co-workers, boss, etc… say that Christ is the most important thing (relationship) in your life? If they wouldn’t there is probably good reason for that (He’s not).

In closing realize that you will hear one of two things on
Judgment Day, “Well done good and faithful servant, or I NEVER knew you depart
from me you work iniquity. May He be your greatest treasure, because (as John
Piper states) God is most glorified in you when you are most satisfied in
Him.”By Evangelist Phil Sessa

title.rendered: Sitting at the Last Passover and First Communion with Christ, Part 1 By Evangelist Phil Sessa <

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Passover was prepared and as shared in the last message, everyone ate the Passover Lamb except for Judas. Following the Passover Lamb, no food was to be eaten, but this would be the tradition in which Jesus would follow. Many call the new meal that Jesus instituted, the Last Supper, however this would not be accurate to say, but rather this would be the Last Passover meal. Even though nothing was to be eaten after the lamb was eaten, Christ lifts up the bread and first gave thanks at the end of the meal; then He proceeded to break it and disperse it among His eleven remaining disciples. He proclaimed, “Take, eat; this is my body.” Was the bread literally his body or a symbol or representation of His body? Remember Jesus ministered in a Jewish culture and therefore the language metaphorical language he used was a typical Hebraism. It represented his body similar to the words of Luke 8:11 where Jesus says that the seed is the Word of God, and therefore “…no Eucharistic miracle of transubstantiation was implied, nor could the disciples have missed the symbolic intent of His statement, for His actual body—yet unbroken—was before their very eyes (John MacArthur).” In the book of John, John records many “I Am statements” that Jesus made to represent Himself which are as follows:

“I am the light of the world (8:12).”; “I am the door of the sheep (10:7, 9)”; “I am the good shepherd (10:11, 14)”; I am the resurrection and the life (11:25)”; “I am the way, the truth, and the life. (14:6)”; “I am the true vine (15:1)”. However imagine if when we turned on the light we thought it to be Christ, or how about walking through a door, seeing a vine, etc…. He was not literal about his body which was right in front of the disciples, and saying that he was holding Himself up in His hands and breaking himself, and then they would eat him, but rather that he would be broken in his flesh on the cross. The distinction must be made that his flesh was broken, because for one to say that he was broken could imply that his whole body was broken and this would include even his bones which Scripture records would not, and were not broken. He lifted the cup and proclaimed,

Then He took the cup, and gave thanks, and gave it to them, saying, “Drink from it, all of you. 28 For this is My blood of the new covenant, which is shed for many for the remission of sins. 29 But I say to you, I will not drink of this fruit of the vine from now on until that day when I drink it new with you in My Father’s kingdom (Matt 26:27–29).”

Let me back up for just a minute to “…the Passover which had looked forward to the sacrifice of Christ; He transformed the seder into an altogether different ceremony, which looks back in remembrance at His atoning death. [1]” The whole meal and all the events leading up to it was about Christ Himself. In Exodus (a type of the world) God was to deliver His people from slavery. In the New Testament God delivered His people from their slavery of sin from the world. God commanded that a Lamb was to be slaughtered and it’s blood applied to the door post and the lintel of the door frame which would indicate to the death angel to Passover the homes that had applied the blood, and spare the children instead of killing them. This was not what happened with the Egyptians however, the first born in each house hold was killed by the plague that was brought by the death angel of God. What do we learn from this? John MacArthur shares the following:

“There’s a simple principle that comes through in that and it is this, to be delivered from judgment requires death. That’s the first thing to think about. To be delivered from judgment requires death. Second, critical, that death can be the death of a substitute. That death can be the death of a substitute. God was saying, “I will spare you, I will deliver you from this judgment if there is the death of an innocent substitute.” The message of the Passover is God delivers through the death of an innocent substitute. From then on, all sacrifices and this is not the first sacrifice, but from then on all sacrifices were clearly indications that God delivers from judgment by the death of a substitute. But the animal sacrifices weren’t that substitute. No person was ever delivered from divine judgment of any animal. The repeated sacrifice of animals was simply a continual symbol of the fact that God does deliver by the death of an innocent substitute but no animal was ever satisfactory to God and so the sacrifices went on and on and on and on by the millions. And the people waited for a sacrifice that would be satisfactory to God which all those unsatisfactory sacrifices pointed.” In summary in the Old Testament God was pacified as it were, but in the death of His Son He was satisfied once and for all, never to be repeated again. If one were to repeat it as was done with the Passover lamb would be to render the sacrifice of Christ useless. This is what the writer of Hebrews in chapter 10 was explaining throughout the entire chapter when he wrote, “For it is not possible that the blood of bulls and goats could take away sins (10:4). “By that will we have been sanctified through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all (10:10).” To continue, blessings Evangelist Phil

[1] MacArthur, J. J. (1997). The MacArthur Study Bible (electronic ed.) (Luke 22:19). Nashville: Word Pub.

title.rendered: Judas and The Passover Lamb?, Part 2, By Evangelist Phil Sessa <

content.rendered:
The Passover and Last Supper

Looking at the Last Supper through the lens of the Passover really brings the communion of Christ into sharper and proper focus.  Jesus and His disciples reclined at the table in the Babylonian custom of free men (Christ in the Passover).  Even though they all positioned themselves as free men, one was bound captive by Satan himself.  “It was during the ceremony of dipping the second sop into the bitter herbs that Jesus said, “One of you SHALL BETRAY ME (Matt. 26:21).”  Now each of the disciples became exceedingly sorrowful during this Passover Celebration, and began to ask him, ‘Lord, is it I (v.22)’”, rather than suspect the trusted treasurer of treason, Judas.  Jesus responds to their question by saying, “…He it is to whom I shall give a sop (John 13:20).”  Why didn’t John stop Judas or why did Jesus not stop him?  It must be remembered that the statement could have been taken to mean any one of them as they all took part of the sop.  However, interestingly enough Judas probably received the sop first to show him “honor” in a mocking way as he was the true  betrayer of Christ openly.  Ironic, I think not! However all of these things were quickly unraveling before the disciples.  They did not have a script, nor the benefit seeing through hindsight of 2,000 years of church history to glean from.

“The Son of Man indeed foes just as it is written of Him, but woe (cursed) to that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed!  It would have been good if he had not been born (Matt 26:24).” Wow, the Creator of Life just stated it would have been BETTER is JUDAS were NEVER even BORN!  The author of Life is certainly justified in speaking these things about His creation.

“Then Judas who was betraying Him answered and said, ‘Rabbi, is it I? He said, ‘You have said it.”  “After the sop Jesus went in to the night to finish his satanically inspired work.  Because he had left before eating the Passover Lamb, he had in effect excommunicated himself from the congregation.  Neither did he have any part in the new memorial which Christ would institute, namely the Last Supper or Communion that followed after supper (Christ and the Passover, 58).”

Summary of the character of Judas

Judas never had an abiding in Christ, rather he was a false disciple.  He was the son of perdition prophesied about (Psalm 41:9; 109:8; John 17:12 ).  He was like the false converts spoken about in Matthew 7:21 – 23 which called Jesus Lord, Lord, and Christ would say depart from Me I NEVER knew you.  He “walked with Christ,” and even performed miracles in His name, but had no communion with the Savior, the foolish man that built his house on the sand (Matt 7:13-14), he was like the fig tree that Christ cursed for being fruitless having much leaves but no fruit, like the branch that was cutoff in John 15, like a whitewashed tomb on outwardly, but inwardly filled with dead men’s bones (Matt. 23:27 ), and like the seed sown that when it grew it was chocked by the thorns (7) because the deceitfulness of riches and desires for other things enter in and choke the word making it unfruitful (18-19).  “Judas was as close as anyone could get to the Savior but as far from salvation [as the east is from the west] (MacArthur, J., F. (1997). The Gospel according to Jesus).”

Application (based on 2 Tim 3:16): Are you a Judas (a false convert) that sits among God’s people but you yourself have never been converted?  If so today is the day to repent and put your trust and abide in Christ. Perhaps you know some Judas’ that need to be confronted, then be a watchman in their lives (Ezekiel 3) and warn them of the coming Judgment (Matt 7:21-23), but only do it as wise as a serpent and gentle as a dove, as you share the truth in love.

title.rendered: Judas and The Passover Lamb?, Part 1, By Evangelist Phil Sessa <

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Matthew 26:23 – 30; John 13:1 – 26

Recently I read Recently I read Christ in the Passover, Why is this Night Different, by Ceil and Moishe Rosen, which came on the coattails of my study of John 15 concerning the Vine and the branches, and the fruit thereof.  God illuminated a correlation to me using these texts which was extremely impacting especially during this time of the Passion Week of Christ.  Hopefully you have already read the message I wrote called “got fruit” which is sort of a preliminary message to this message. 

It was during the Passover time that Jews came from all over to flood into Jerusalem to commemorate the Passover.  This was in remembrance of the period of history when the Lord took His people Israel out of bondage from the Land of Egypt.  After nine plagues which bombarded the Egyptians by the Hand of their enemy, Yahweh (God), Moses proclaimed that a tenth would come and plague the land.  This plague would be none other than the death of the first born sons of the Egyptians.  If you recall this is what the Pharaoh did when Moses was a child to try and kill the sons of Israel to keep them from multiplying and outnumbering the Egyptians.  It would seem that this was satanically inspired to attempt kill Moses who would grow to become the deliverer of Israel.  However, God used Moses’ mother Jochebed to thwart those plans.  When Moses announced the tenth plague was coming, Israel didn’t need “plagues for dummies,” they knew nine plague warning were accompanied by nine plagues, and therefore Moses words would be followed by the plague he proclaimed.   The fathers of Israel were instructed to kill a male lamb, without blemish and to strike the blood on the two posts and on the upper door post of the houses.  Why was this so?  God said, “For I will pass through the land of Egypt…and will smite all the firstborn…And the blood shall be to you for a token upon the houses,…and when I see the blood I will pass over you, and the plague shall not be upon you (Exodus 12:3 – 7, 12 – 13).  Hence the lives of Israel’s children would be saved, and the lives of the Egyptian’s firstborn males would be lost because they were not protected by the blood, but were in fact enemies of God and His people.

Now let us travel ahead to the night the disciples were gathered together to commemorate the Passover with Christ.  There were two major events would take place at the house were they gathered for the Passover, one was foot washing, and the second was the meals. 

The Washing (John 13):

Jesus would remove his outer garments and take up a towel “…taking the form of a bondservant (Phil 2)…”,and would wash each of the feet of his disciples.  He began to wash them one by one, however “…the devil having already put it into the heart of Judas to betray him (13:2).  Jesus then arrived at Peter who initially refused the foot washing by the Master saying, “You shall never wash my feet.”  Christ replies, If I do not wash you, you have no part with Me.”  Peter responds to Him saying, “Lord not my feet only, but also my hands and my head (8–9)!”  Jesus answers by saying, “…he who bathed needs only to wash his feet, but is completely clean; and you are clean but NOT all of you.”  Who was Christ referring to when he made this statement among his twelve, which one was NOT clean among them?  Hopefully it is blatantly obvious that Judas had his feet washed by Christ outwardly just as the others had received, but he was not bathed inwardly as it states in Jeremiah 17:9: “The heart is deceitful above all things, And desperately wicked; Who can know it? 0I, the Lord, search the heart, I test the mind, Even to give every man according to his ways, According to the fruit of his doings.

Christ served each one of his disciples and modeled how to serve, however Judas was not serving Christ but rather in the midst of betraying Him!  Perhaps Judas not Peter should have been the one to refuse the foot washing.  However a betrayers heart instead of a servants heart is what resided within the life of Judas, as he sought his true god, 30 pieces of silver.  Jesus summoned up His foot washing lesson when he instructed them saying, “If I them being your LORD [Lit. YAHWEH] and Teacher haved, have washed your feet, you also ought to wash one another’s feet. For I have given you an example, that you should do as I have done to you (14 – 15).” 


To continue,

blessings

Pastor Phil

title.rendered: Got Fruit?, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

 “I
am the vine, you are the branches. He who abides in Me, and I in him, bears much fruit; for without Me you can do nothing (John 15:5).”

When looking in the Old Testament, God often portrayed and compared Israel  to a vineyard.  This can be seen in passages such as Isa. 5:7, and in Jer. 2 whereby God rebukes Israel, which Jesus uses indeed as a backdrop here in John 15.  Christ is just about to go to the cross, and is giving some final instructions to His disciples.  Therefore what did Christ emphasize to His eleven disciples, because recall there was one of them that was not present at this proclamation of Christ, hence Judas.  Having this backdrop can now allow us to get to what Christ was actually getting at in this passage.   The various persons represented in the illustration, the aspects of relationships, the whole reality of what fruit bearing is, and the timing of this passage is things which must be looked at in order to really unpack passage.

First let’s look at Who’s who.  God is the vinedresser who is responsible to protect, water, prune the fruit bearing branches and remove the unfruitful branches.  The vine represented Christ Himself who gives life to the branches that are connected to the vine.  The branches are those disciples and the fruit was the result of that which would come from
the branches connected to the life giving vine. 

Secondly realize there were eleven fruit bearing disciples, and one non-fruit bearing disciple.  When looking at the lives of the disciples and Apostles from Foxe’s Book of Martyrs,one can clearly see that those that followed Christ as His disciples produced fruit, the fruit of the Spirit which produced Christ likeness but ultimately to the fruit of other disciples.  In his book The Secrets of the Vine by Bruce Wilkerson focused on the fruit.  He shared that there were four baskets beneath the vine and that each basket had a certain amount of fruit in each.  Basket one had no fruit (v. 2a,6) , basket two had
some fruit (v. 2b,4), basket three held more fruit (v. 7) and finally the fourth basket contained much fruit (v. 26).  The problem that the author gets wrong deals with the fruitless branch, believing that God lifts up the fruitless branch so that it becomes fruitful.  However, that is not what the passage states; it states that the vinedresser does something very different.  John MacArthur states, “The picture is of the vinedresser (i.e., the Father) getting rid of dead wood so that the
living, fruit bearing branches may be sharply distinguished. This is a picture of apostate Christians who never genuinely believed and will be taken away in judgment (v. 6; Matt. 7:16; Eph. 2:10); the transforming life of Christ has never pulsated within them (8:31, 32; cf. Matt. 13:18–23; 24:12; Heb. 3:14–19; 6:4–8; 10:27–31; 1 John 2:19; 2 John 9).”  The unfruitful branch Christ is speaking of is none other than Judas!  There are many false converts (Judas’) that sit among the people of God, they may look like branches, but God is the fruit inspector and when He looks at them He sees them in truth, and unless they repent and put their faith in Christ, will cut them off and see that they are burned (end up in Hell)!  Does this sound like God is a mean cruel and judgmental God to you?  God is certainly judgmental (He is the perfect Just Judge of the universe) but He is certainly kind, so kind as to save His people from their sin  Hence upon removing the dead branches, he also prunes His children, which are bearing fruit, so they might bear more fruit for His glory.  The purpose for bearing fruit is that God is glorified, and true disciples will bear fruit because the power and life is in the vine and will flow through to the branches. 

Thirdly, what does God use to both punish the unfruitful and prune the fruitful?  He uses a Blade which is His Word (Heb 4:12; 2 Tim 3:16), the Handle of His Sword is the affliction and persecution He allows to come upon His children to make them more Christ like (Mark 4, Matt. 13; 2 Tim 3:12), and he uses His Church to spur one another (Heb 10:24-25, Prov. 27:17; Gal 2:11).  He uses His pure unadulterated Word to condemn, punish and cut off the ungodly (Exo. 20; Rom 7, Gal 3:24, John 3:10-21).  Yes this is a picture of judgment.  In contrasting Peter verse Judas both that were chosen by Christ, one can see that Peter denied Christ, and Judas betrayed Him.  Christ pruned Peter (Luke 22:31-34; John 21:15-17) and condemned Judas (Mark 14:17-21).

The branches give nothing to the vine, but by it’s fruit it glorifies the vine.  What must a branch do to produce fruit, it must ABIDE!  The relationship in Christ must be cultivated; it must stay dependent upon Christ, and must stand in total reliance upon Christ for apart for Christ His children can do nothing.

Application (based on 2 Tim 3:16):  If you are connected to Christ, how has your abiding been lately?

title.rendered: We Must Die, by Bro Ben

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Colossians 3:3- For you died, and your life is hidden with Christ in God.

As we remember the Lord’s death and resurrection this week, may we reflect on the example He has left for us. We are called throughout scripture to die to ourselves, to die to self, and to give ourselves entirely unto Jesus. This is the life of holiness, the life of devotion, the life of a true disciple, to reckon ourselves dead indeed to sin, dead to ourselves, and alive to God alone. We see Jesus walking down the Via Delorosa, the way of suffering, and He is calling us to follow Him, for in order for there to truly be new life, there must be first a death. We must die to ourselves if we are truly to be made alive in Christ. He calls us to bear our cross daily, but where do we think we are heading? Where did our Savior head? If we are following His example, we are also going to our death. The cross is not an ornament to wear around our necks, it is for us to die upon, just as Jesus did.

In Romans 6:5, Paul tells us that IF we want to be united with Him in the likeness of His resurrection, we must first be united with Him in His death. We must die, first to sin, then to ourselves each day, more and more, until we cease to exist, and only Christ lives within us, we are now hidden in Him. We must die moment by moment, crying out along with Jesus, Not my will, but Thy will be done, until Jesus is all that remains. He desires to cleanse us to the uttermost, to fill every aspect of our lives, and if we will let go of our lives, O how He will fill each life. But it takes the moment by moment death, until we are indeed dead. A man may be dying for some time, but when he is dead he is dead, and in that moment God fills that life.

This is His desire and will for each life, that we would die to ourselves, that He might sanctify us wholly. Sanctification is the result of this death of self, it is the act of His grace whereby a man is made holy, not by growth, but by an instantaneous work of God within the heart. It is the effect of the life laid upon the cross, the further work of God’s grace within the heart. Trust in Jesus, and entrust your life completely to Him. He asks nothing less than full devotion, and He truly deserves nothing less than that. Forsake sin, forsake yourself, this Resurrection Sunday, as the world celebrates rabbits and eggs and all the things thought up to distract them from the true meaning of the day, may we each truly experience God deep within our souls, and may we truly give Him our hearts.

May the Lamb that was slain receive the reward of His suffering,a

In His love and truth, Brother Benjamen

title.rendered: Overcoming Life Obstacles Part 5, by Bro Boaz

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Luke 2:22, “Then because of Divine warning in a dream not to return to Herod, they went back to their own country by a different route”. (Modern Language),
Luke 2:22, “And being warned of God, in a dream that they should not return to Herod, they departed into their own country another way. King James

Today’s word, Change course, if necessary. Everyone dreams of becoming something, or having success or loving someone and or marrying that someone or going somewhere or achieving some goals etc. These are some of the dreams and desires which, when fulfilled, add excitement, joy and happiness in our lives. God, our Heavenly Father wants us to joyous, successful and happy. However, most of the time, we don’t actualize these. We often face unpredictable challenges, traps and even danger that in some cases kill our dreams and us.

We have an enemy whose mission is to steal, kill and destroy (John 10:10). He does not care who we are or where we are. He will make every attempt to kill us. He schemes plans everyday to track us down to either stop us from being what God meant for us to be or kill us. But, the good news is, “we are safe with God, even in the valley of the shadow of death…we shall fear no evil because God is with us.” (Psalms 23) He also will guide our way. At times, He will change our plans or routes that we intended to take. For instance, He may let you go to a career you never wanted or marry someone you never thought you could marry or lead you to a town or city you never wanted to live in. He may at times instruct you to move from somewhere or out of a relationship with someone you feel you love for or care about. But whatever He does or instruct you to do, His intention is always good. He will only change your plans that may not fit in with His will for you. He will also change routes if He sees danger a head on the way you are going. He will instruct or warn you not to do something or head another way. It is important, therefore, for us the children of God to be flexible and willing to change route or our plans when God tells us to. How then can we know His will? Well His will is His word. Listen to the word. Listen to good counsel. Listen to yourself and, align what you are listening to the word. If you obey, you may save yourself from future pain, failure or hardship or death. Don’t insist on your ways always. Don’t have the mentality most people have “my way or no way.” Don’t compromise to please people or pride yourself to death. And don’t think that you are very “mature” and “strong” and that you can make it alone. None of us is, we all need God’s leading because he, alone, knows the way that we take.

Job said “He knows the way that I take, after He has tried me, I shall come forth like gold” (Job 23:10). Do you believe that God knows the way or road or path that you need to follow into your future dreams? Do you believe that God has a good plan for you to give you your expectation (Jeremiah 29:11)? If you believe God and all His promises, then let go of yourself and let God change your plans and lead you to any path He may choose whether you understand it or not. Heed to his warnings and you shall live and stay out of a lot of troubles and traps of Satan.

If you don’t, you may miss or lose something. For example:

  • Samson lost his divine power, eyes and finally died tragically, because he didn’t heed God’s and his parent’s warning and advise not to love and marry Philistine women;
  • Saul lost his kingship career, was rejected by God and died in battle, a tragic death
  • Many children of Israelites died in the wilderness because they ignored God’s instruction, and his servant Moses’ leadership: If you heed God’s warnings, and follow, His instructions, be willing to change route yourself or let Him do so at will, you will avoid a lot of, if not all, obstacles in life including premature death or evil Satan may bring your way and mine. For example:
  • The Wise men, who announced the good news of Jesus’ birth, went back to their country through a different route. God warned them not to go to Herod. They escaped death!
  • Joseph and his young wife and infant (baby Jesus) escaped to Egypt, through a different route, and had their baby escape infanticide by the hand of Herod. “…Rise, take your child and his mother and escape to Egypt, and remain there until I tell you …And he arose and took the child and his mother by night. And departed to Egypt, and remained there until the death of Herod.” (Mathew 2:13-15)

Is there anything, issue or problem that is or has really been an obstacle in your life? Review carefully, honestly and prayerfully on your beliefs, attitudes, motivations, associations, plans, dreams and desires etc., and if you are convinced and convicted that you need to change route, then do it. And do it today. You shall live and have good success (Josh: 1:8),

Blessings
Bro Boaz

title.rendered: Overcoming Life Obstacles Part 4, by Bro Boaz

content.rendered:
Good morning friends,

1John 5:4, “He that is born of God overcomes the world and this is the victory that overcomes the world even our faith”.

Overcoming an obstacle by climbing on top of its roof and tearing it down courageously by faith, and with great determination, pushing on until you reach Jesus for your miracle, is the subject of today’s devotion.

I hope and pray that we can learn some more on things that will help grow our faith so we can be more prepared to overcome many of life’s hindrances we face every day.

In yesterday’s message, I emphasized two virtues that are necessary for overcoming an obstacle that may require going round it for a long time. These virtues are Faith and Patience. Today, I would like to emphasize again the virtue of faith, in addition to determination, and courage, as necessary tools for tearing down the roof tops of any obstacle that may stand in the way, between you and Jesus, hindering you from receiving your desired miracle.

Have you ever been excited about something you had been promised and were expecting? I mean some things you really would love to have or see and then all over sudden, something happens and you couldn’t have it or see it?. That usually triggers disappointment that can degenerate into discouragement and serious depression. Is there anything that can be done before getting that far? That depends on what choices and decisions you make. You can let obstacles get over your roof and tear you down or you can chose to climb over the rooftops of your obstacles, tear them down, and zoom right into the presence of Christ for your miracle. “… I have set before you this day life and death, blessings and cursing, chose life…”(Deut.30-30).

There are four people the Bible talks about in the Gospel of Mark 2, who could not allow anything to stop them from reaching Jesus so they could fulfill a promise they had given to a paralytic man they had picked from the street where he was begging. These four men had faith in Jesus. They believed that Jesus could heal the paralytic and set him free so he could move on with a normal and productive happy life. They told the paralytic about Jesus and the man liked the idea. So, they trekked down the dusty road, and finally reached the house where Jesus was teaching and preaching the kingdom of God. When they arrived, the house was full to capacity and the crowd could not allow them to pass through to Jesus. What did they do? They made a faith decision, no obstacle was going to stop them from seeing Jesus. They climbed the rooftop, tore the roof, tied the paralytic man’s bed with a rope and lowered him as fast as they could right in front of Jesus.

When Jesus saw their faith, he said, “Son, your sins are forgiven you.” Note what he saw-their faith. That made him stop what He was doing to give the men who had faith what they badly needed-the restoration of the paralytic’s health and extension of his life. He saw and honored their faith. He didn’t even bother to ask them who they were and where they had come from or why they had committed a property damage crime. He didn’t yell at them for disturbing his meeting and changing His program. He gave them what they came for and claimed by faith and by all means.

The decisions taken by the four men and the paralytic exhibits faith, courage and determination, without which they could not have gone passed the crowed to Jesus. If we also want to see Jesus, and bring all our cares to Him, we must make up our mind that we will climb over the rooftops of anything, including: doubts, fear, ignorance, pride, confusion, disappointment, poverty or wealth, laziness, lies, un-forgiveness, bitterness, racism, religion, traditions, etc. And tear them down and lower ourselves in God’s presence. Then, we will receive whatever we have need of according to His will. The Bible says that if we humble ourselves under the mighty hands of God, He will lift us up in due season. That won’t happen if we are not decided, determined, and courageous enough to take drastic steps of faith for overcoming any obstacle we may face in life. Blessings Bro Boaz

title.rendered: Overcoming Life Obstacles Part 3, by Bro Boaz

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“And the Lord said to Joshua, see, i have given into your hand Jericho…and you shall compass the city…and go round about the city once. This you will do six days, and you shall compass the city seven times…” Joshua 6:2-3, 5.

We shared on Plowing through the obstacles, this morning he will be sharing on Going Round the obstacles as we continue to learn how to overcome life obstacles.

Our main text, from the Bible, is found in the book of Joshua 6: 1-27. I recommend that you read the whole chapter, after work, quietly and meditate on it. God will reveal more great things to you.

First, let me say that in life, there are obstacles that will not be easily plowed through or problems that will be solved quickly or instantly. But they can be solved and will be resolved, if the right strategy or approach is used. In most cases, a great deal of spiritual weapons and personal qualities or virtues are necessary for overcoming deeply rooted, and tough to move, change or plow through. One of these virtues that anybody hopping to go the long haul with an obstacle is: Patience. Let me repeat it: Patieeeeeeeence! Someone once said, “Patience is a tree whose roots are bitter, but its fruits are sweet.” It is also said that, “Patience it the Queen of virtues.” When this queen is joined together with, “Faith”, king of virtues, there is no obstacle or problem or difficulty or circumstance that can stand on their way. Everything bows before them, and departs with great regrets, sorrow and disappointment. They turn disappointment into appointment with God for achievement of your dreams and arrival at your destiny. In order to develop these virtues, you must get accustomed to doing three things consistently: 1.) You must trust God, 2.) You must communicate (prayer) with God, 1.) You must listen to God, mostly, through His word-the Bible.

In our today’s text, Joshua, who was leading the Israelites to their conquest faced an impossible obstacle- Jericho City. They could not move ahead without passing through Jericho. The wall of Jericho was very high and firm. The foundation of the wall was carefully and strongly laid, reinforced such that the children of Israel could not, whatsoever, enter to attack and destroy and loot the good stuff that was locked in there. Can you imagine the frustration of Joshua and the Israelites?

If you have faced some things that just blocked you so that no matter what you did or didn’t do, you couldn’t move on or make progress or have breakthrough, then you may empathize with these children of God. Remember, I didn’t say “sympathize.” (Personally I don’t like that word that much. Sympathy is one of those commodities I don’t consume that much and I don’t enjoy very much the company of people who offer me sympathy for whatever reason). Anyway, that is beside the point.

Anyway, how did Joshua and his people overcome the wall of Jericho? The Bible says that God gave them a strategy. He told them to gather together and quietly go round the city seven times for seven days. And on the seventh day, they would shout with a big shout, blowing their trumpets. And when they did that, the scripture says “ …, the people shouted…and it came to pass, when the people heard, and the people shouted with a great shout, that the wall fell flat, so that the people went up into the city…and the took the city.” (vs.20). Amen!

What a simple, stupid, senseless, childish and irrational strategy God gave Joshua. How could he and his troop, as intelligent and sensible as all of them were, believe what God said? Well, they didn’t care whether it made sense or not, they just acted it and got the result. Sometimes God will say things to you that don’t make sense. Victory from God is won by faith not by understanding or working hard or by use of powerful things or even people. The just shall live by faith…not by works. Today many of you are probably facing obstacles that you have tried to overcome for a long time but you have not been able. Listen to God and start going round the obstacle. You may have to do that continuously for a long time. May be seven hours, or seven days, or weeks or months or even years. Don’t give up. Each time you go round it, you are weakening the walls of your obstacles. They will soon fall down, never again to be seen. Have a blessed going around your wall day!!! Blessings Bro Boaz

title.rendered: Overcoming Life Obstacles, Part 2 by Bro. Boaz

content.rendered:
Good morning,

There are seven strategies or approaches to dealing with obstacles that I would like to share. They are not the only ones, nor are they the super strategies for overcoming all of life’s obstacles we face daily. But they are good and godly, and are time tested, as the Bible will prove and as some of us will confirm from our testimonies and past experiences and victories God have given us. I will begin today by examining the first strategy or approach:

Plowing Through The Obstacle, When faced with an obstacle, small or big, our common reaction is usually a response or a reaction. Reaction seems to be the option most of us prefer because, I guess, it is cheap since no much thought or consideration or concentration or efforts are necessary. For instance, if you are facing a disappointment as an obstacle, you can simply deal with it by deciding to give up or quit or cry afoul or curse. Worse, you can choose to sink and drown in the deep ocean of depression, where hopelessness and frustration are manifested in large quantity free of charge. Now that’s very dangerous, because most people don’t get out of that sea senile or at, worse, a live. You know that. Don’t you? Try not to be a statistic. Don’t go there.

But what about “response” to an obstacle? I mean in a positive manner that is likely to produce the best and most desirable and victorious result? That may demand a lot more than any reactions I have already mentioned. It may mean making a conscious decision, however risky or painful or hard or challenging the obstacle may be, that you are going to “plow” right through it. Your choices and decisions determine the outcome. Your dependence on God for help guarantees the victory, which is usually accompanied by a lot of joy and celebrations. Listen to what the Psalmist wrote: “Weeping may endure for a night, but Joy comes in the morning (Psalms 30:5).

There is a morning that always comes for those who decide to go through their obstacle, even when they are weeping so hard. They know that the weeping is just but for a night. Don’t let Satan lie to you that your obstacle is unique and special, just newly invented and that you do not have the ability and capacity to overcome it. Our God is able. His specialty is deliverance. His presence alone, even without doing anything or saying anything, melts any obstacle or problem. He is also a good road constructor. He makes ways where roads never existed and no Engineer could ever imagine a road could be constructed. Come with me to the Bank of the Red Sea and see how He did that to Moses and the children of Israel, when they faced the impossible to “plow” through -The Red Sea. Read Exodus 14, and see what God can do. It records one of the most spectacular and incredible miracle of victory over and a gigantic and life threatening obstacle. The first thing God said to the Israelites was “stand still” and see my “ salvation which I am going to show you today.” In other words, don’t panic or be scared. I am with you and I am in control of the situation. The reality was they were scared to death, because Pharaoh’s soldiers were behind them ready to kill them or recapture them and take them the back to slavery and the Red Sea was in front of them. Now, look, these guys were in a” fix”. But God was not scared! Anytime you face an obstacle, stand still. You will see God’s hand and power melting your problems, fears, doubts, and all those things that are frustrating you and causing pain and at the same time stopping you from reaching your maximum potential God intended for you.

The second thing God did was “He told Moses to stretch his rod over the Red Sea, and divide the sea.” A dry way opened up right before their eyes and they were commanded to walk through it to the other side. Wow! What a miracle! You see, God gave Moses an idea and a plan for overcoming the impossible. He acted on them and they worked. You too need a plan and an idea from God for overcoming. You can thrive on God’s ideas, thoughts, plans and wisdom. Seek them from His word. You will never overcome successfully on your own, no matter how much you try. If you don’t want to drown and die, then you must decide to dedicate yourself to God and depend on Him absolutely without “if” or “but”, or maybe etc. If you want to sing today and have a happy celebration, then make a decision to go through any of your present or future obstacles with God. Use what you have to make what you need happen.

After the Israelites plowed through their obstacle, they sang a song of praise and worship to God. Praise and worship are inevitable, when facing obstacles, and after victory is won. “Then sang Moses and the children of Israel unto the Lord this song, saying, I will sing unto the Lord, for He has triumphed gloriously…” Exodus 15:1

Read the rest of the song for yourself. You really need to read, later on if you can’t now these two chapters from Bible. With open heart and willingness to learn, hear from God, and adopt the lessons or strategies revealed, your life will never be the same again.

Let us pray: Our father in Heaven, we thank you for being there for us when we don’t know what to do. We ask you to help us face our obstacles with courage and trust in your power, for victory and deliverance, whenever we face an obstacle. In Jesus name. Amen

Blessings
Bro Boaz

title.rendered: Overcoming Life Obstacles, Part 1

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Life has many obstacles. We all face them every day. The obstacles hinder us from being where we are supposed to be or want to be. Overcoming obstacles of any kind is not easy, especially when you are trying on your own. Naturally, as human beings, we have limited power, strength, knowledge, abilities, and many other resources that can and should be used to overcome obstacles.

There are many ways and approaches that have been advanced by professionals, philosophers, or even lay people throughout all generations for dealing with obstacles in life. To some extent, some people have overcome great obstacles in their personal life using their own ways, methods, or even tactics and strategies. Many have also failed and some have even died without experiencing any breakthroughs with their life’s obstacles. And even today, there are countless peoples who are trapped and have been stopped from moving any further because they face insurmountable obstacles that they cannot go through or past. Such people need help! I HAPPEN TO BE AMONG THOSE THAT NEED HELP. Do you?

WELL, I do not know what your answer to that question is; I also do not know what your situation is either. But I do know that if you are like all of us, living here on earth, where there are countless problems and challenges that people face every day, then you need help. And help is available!

There is an enemy- a common enemy of mankind who is busy building obstacles: gates, walls etc to stop you and I from experiencing the victorious and abundant life God meant for all of us. We are all God’s creation. We were created, formed and made by God for a purpose greater than ourselves, and with unlimited potential to become anything He wanted us to be. But mankind lost it through wrong choice. Choosing to be independent, and live a life of self without God. This deviation from God’s plan is one reason we have problems, difficulties and obstacles we cannot overcome on our own. It is also the reason why we are cached and limited and powerless, so that we cannot live victorious lives.

I would like to share with you some insights and strategies that you can use as a Christian to help you overcome any obstacle you may be facing right now or in the future. Here are some Seven Strategies for Overcoming Obstacles.

1. Plow Through the obstacle:
2. Go round it:
3. Climb over it:
4. Change the route:
5. Re-position yourself:
6. Review the situation:
7. Break the obstacle in pieces and deal with the pieces one by one.

To continue, Have a great day. Blessings Bro Boaz

title.rendered: He Moves Me And Grows Me

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Romans 5:1-20, 3 And not only that, but we also glory in tribulations, knowing that tribulation produces perseverance; 4 and perseverance, character; and character, hope”

In order to function effectively as Christians, we constantly need to remind ourselves that we are nomadic people here on earth. God is working on us helping us to climb from glory to glory

In Romans 5:1 tells us “Therefore being justified by faith, we have peace with God”, this verse opens the door for us to be saved, the beginning of growth as we move (grow). This is justification which God does for us and none of us has a part in our justification by faith. It’s like we’ve passed an exam we did not sit for and could not pass on our own. Because we are justified, we have peace with God meaning the war God had with us through our wicked mind has been settled by Christ on the cross.

Vs. 2, “Through whom also we have access by faith into this grace in which we stand, and rejoice in hope of the glory of God. Grace is what we don’t deserve, God’s unmerited favor. When you understand that you are favored, you rejoice, as you know that this isn’t the end but the beginning and so your faith is elevated for you know who is holding your life.

These two verses about sanctification is where we struggle to embrace, Vs. 3 And not only that, but we also glory in tribulations, knowing that tribulation produces perseverance; 4 and perseverance, character; and character, hope. “if we rejoice and glory in favor, we need to remember that we can also rejoice and glory in tribulation. I know not of a great tool to grow one than the school master of tribulations. It’s through it that people pray more, it’s an agent of purification, if channeled properly helps you see God in ways you could never imagine or think. David in Psalm 119:71 tells us how beneficial tribulations are, “It is good for me that I have been afflicted, That I may learn Your statutes”. Affliction, tribulation of any kind acts as a wholesome discipline in leading the pious more highly to value the truth and promises of God

When we glory in tribulation, we understand that tribulations are just for a season and joy is eternal. Tribulation (hardships) tailors one into patience (perseverance), as patience is not something that is taught in a classroom setting, it mastered and learnt in the sea of life. Patience builds experience (character). Having gone through hardships and patience, you become wise and experienced in giving advice, counsel, make wise decision as to where to run to for help, and what paths not to take. Character produces Hope and hope does not a shame. It’s in tribulation that a saint should hold on to Christ tight and hope for the life to come. God knows how to take us through the process of life that He may make us be like Jesus, people of character, people who can be at peace during tough times while the world is in chaos. All this work is to make us bear fruit, more fruit and much fruit. The gardener has to prune, dig around the tree, and remove the weeds that hinder that tree from bearing fruits. And if the tree is bearing fruit’s, he still works on it to bear more and much. There are certain tough things the Lord has allowed in our lives to teach us patience in our work places, friends, family, and as we go through them our character is being enlarged. We learn to love the unloving, we learn to forgive and even pray for those who despitefully use us, we learn to put ourselves in someone else shoes to feel their pain. I thank God that He moves me from stage to stage with His hands upon my life. Even in the midst of tribulations, I know that it’s working for His purpose and I’m learning things I could not learn in any other way, bearing fruit, more fruit and much fruit. The more He moves me, the more he grows me in Him. Blessings Ev

title.rendered: Better And Not Bigger

content.rendered:
Good morning,

2Cor 12:9, “My grace is sufficient for thee, my strength is made perfect in weakness”

Sometimes ago I started to experience something with my car I had not experienced before. I watched it closely as I was driving and realized it was losing power. Breaking sound from the exhaust system made it more clear and I wondered what was wrong with my car. Later I took it to a garage where they found the car needed tune up. The plugs were not firing properly and my fueling system was out of place. The car was still performing but not with power.

Wondering why I’m talking to you about my car? You may be feeling tired, worn out, spent, finished, exhausted. And your current state is affecting your life for you cannot function effectively like you should. Yes you are functioning but not with power. Just like my car, it was still performing but not with power simply because it did not have strength it needed. Everyone needs strength to make it up the mountain, strength to fight the enemy, strength to accomplish a task. When there is no strength we become vulnerable and less effective. God has His garage (if I may use this term) where we can go and be restored and strengthened again. I was told my plugs were not firing properly let’s look at this in the Spiritual realm, your prayer life plug is weak, reading the word plug is weak too, witnessing plug is weak and reaching others plug is weak so what happens, you find it hard to perform your duties at work, home, ministry because your plugs are not firing enough strength to your life.

2Cor 12:9, “My grace is sufficient for thee, my strength is made perfect in weakness” We need to understand that God’s grace is more than enough. Grace is given and not earned. We are told that it’s more than enough for them that are His. Can you imagine receiving grace and new mercies everyday and yet it never runs out? The bible says “My strength is made perfect in weakness”. I love this line for it reminds me that His strength is completely made perfect in my weakness in other words, it was already there, fits like a glove regardless of what happened when I lost my strength. When you come to His shop, He will boost your strength into perfection even in your weakness. Psalm 46:1, “God is my refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble”, The strength in our lives is God Himself so many times when we feel weak and tired in the Spirit, we need to check again to see who is in control of our strength.

Psalm 73:26, “My flesh and my heart fails, but God is the strength of my heart, and my portion forever”, We can’t put our confidence in the flesh, the psalmist tells us the flesh and the heart fails but God is the strength of our heart. Thank God for His strength, you may have a lot to do and should be complaining and murmuring, you should be looking gloomy and you should be mean to people who hand you more work but because you know the Lord is the strength of your heart, you will draw strength from Him and give your job, ministry, home 110% for your hope and strength is built on nothing less than Jesus. Everyone will expect you to be overwhelmed and sink but you will sail on top of what other people are sinking in for God is tuning you up, taking off the old plugs clogged with dirt, cleaning the fuel system and making it clear that your strength may be back. You still have more mountains to climb, more valleys to go through, more work to do. You still need to clock more miles than men ever expected for God has given you His strength

Caleb in the Old Testament was 80 years old but he felt like 40 for he says the same strength he had when he was 40 is the same strength he had when he was 80. “I can do all things, survive all things, deal with all things, face all things through Christ who strengthens me Phi 4:13. Psalm 18:1-3, “I will love thee Oh Lord, my strength, the Lord is my rock, and my fortress, and my deliverer, my God, my strength: my buckler, and the horn of my salvation, and my High Tower. I will call upon the name of the Lord who is worthy to be praised so shall I be saved from my enemies”. Isaiah 26:1, “Trust in the Lord forever: for in the Lord Jehovah is everlasting strength”

God is interested in seeing us get strong and perform His duties. We know for sure we cannot by ourselves that’s why in Him we live and move and have our beings. Every day we will be strong because He makes us strong but we always need to go to His garage (prayer room, His word) for tune up for the race ahead. Now my car went through restoration to a position in which it was not when I bought it, watch this, my car was not made bigger having been tuned up, it was made better. The Lord will not bring us a secretary or greater machines and the like to do greater things, He will equip us to be better in any place He plants us. Be unique in all that you do for God’s strength is unique. Feeling weak and tired, take a few minutes and walk to His throne for tune up and expect to be made better and not bigger. Blessings Ev

title.rendered: The Captain Of The Host, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Joshua 5:3 “And it came to pass, when Joshua was by Jericho, that he lifted up his eyes and looked, and, behold, there stood a man over against him with his sword drawn in his hand: and Joshua went unto him, and said unto him, Art thou for us, or for our adversaries? And he said, Nay; but as captain of the host of the LORD am I now come. And Joshua fell on his face to the earth, and did worship, and said unto him, What saith my lord unto his servant? And the captain of the LORD’S host said unto Joshua, Loose thy shoe from off thy foot; for the place whereon thou standest is holy. And Joshua did so.”

On the night of Israel’s attack on Jericho, Joshua personally surveyed the area surrounding the city, inspecting the fortress walls. As the military leader of Israel Joshua, was strategizing by examining up the situation set before him. The words “he looked up” convey that Joshua was surprised. “A man” is what Joshua thought he was seeing, but subsequent events reveal that it was no ordinary man. The man’s “drawn sword” was symbolic of God’s participation in the coming battle. When he saw the man standing there ready for combat it provoked Joshua to inquire whether he was friend or foe. Joshua needed to find out whose side this man was on, could he be trusted; would he help or hinder Joshua’s military operation? These were important questions that he needed answers for.

The stranger’s response put everything in proper perspective. God is the sovereign leader. It is never a question whether God is on our side but whether we are on God’s side. This is a perspective to take into each of our situation. Don’t try to fit God in your will, but pray “Thy will be done” and in doing so “My will be gone.” The stranger came as “captain of the host of the LORD “; Joshua therefore was to be subservient to him.

Though he does not reappear in the story of the Conquest, the stranger was a heavenly being who fought behind the scenes in the spiritual realm. His presence showed a sign that the Lord was the real military leader of the Conquest. Many identify this person as the angel of the Lord, while others cannot distinguish him from the Lord himself (as in Exod 3:2-4:17; Judg 6:11-23) this captain of the host was the leader of the army (host) of heaven. He didn’t say that he was a captain, but THE CAPTAIN! I don’t know about you but that sounds to me like the words of my Jesus. Why do I say this because the name of Jesus is significant, as the Grecized (Greek) form of “Joshua” is “Jesus.” Joshua was perhaps in charge, militarily of the army of Israel, but the Captain of the host was leader of the entire angelic host. Stay with me now. This reminds me of what Jesus said in Matt. 25:53 in the context of Jesus talking about power when Peter cut off the ear of the soldier. Jesus then makes the statement “Do you not think that I cannot now pray to my Father, and he shall presently give me more than twelve legions of angels? A full Roman legion was six thousand men, and Jesus perhaps was conveying that he could call to? His assistance perhaps one legion for Jesus and one for each of the eleven disciples if He so chose to. But Jesus was fighting a spiritual battle not a physical one. This was more than the eyes of faith seeing help as in 2 Kings 6:17 but the knowledge that help was available, yet He refused to use it, unlike perhaps most of us would have done, because He was laying His life down for final victory (John 10:18).

Though “Joshua fell facedown,” we cannot be sure that he realized he was in the presence of a supernatural being. In that culture persons would prostrate themselves before anyone in authority. Moreover, when Joshua said “Lord,” he used the Hebrew word ‘Adoni which was used to address human beings. He did not use the divine name “Yahweh,” which is translated “LORD” in English, written with small capitals. This encounter was not to impart commands but to inspire Joshua with humility and reverence and to instill in him the confidence that God was with him and He was really in control of the battle. So many times we try to be the captain of the battle, and yet we cannot just sit on our hands, but the real captain is Jesus, The Captain of the hosts.

Application: Do you seek to be in the presence of the Captain, or are you trying to fight life’s battles with your own physical power. Remember spiritual battles cannot be won by physical means. Blessings Pastor Phil

title.rendered: Fearfully And Wonderfully Designed

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Genesis 30:1, “Now when Rachel saw that she bore Jacob no children, Rachel envied her sister, and said to Jacob, “Give me a child, or else I die”

If at all I was to ask different people about how they think about themselves, I will have a long list. You may have something about that you don’t like. If God was to give you a chance to design who you would like to be, most likely you will have a completely different picture of the new you. Every time you look in the mirror, is there a part of you, you wished you could change? Humans tend to concentrate more on what they don’t have or what someone else has that they forget to appreciate what they have. We at times feel that we have nothing to offer and there is nothing in our lives that other people can admire and therefore we belittle ourselves because of what we think. Psalm 139:14, “I will praise thee; for I am fearfully and wonderfully made; marvelous are thy works; and my soul knoweth right well”. You and I are skillfully, wonderfully and uniquely designed to fit in this world. You are not in this world by accident. The Porter took time to make you in an image that no one else in the world is like you. There may be people who look and sound like you but there is absolutely no one like you. In other words, you have no competition; no one can beat you being you. The design on your thumb is unique no one in the world has the same design as yours. You are unique, with unique qualities, unique design.

We are told in Genesis about Rachel and Leah, blood sisters married to one man. Both women are from the same womb but are very different. They are unique in their looks, personality, age wise and many more things. The husband appreciates each of them differently. I want us to understand that we can belong to God but be very different. The difference is what brings about our individuality and uniqueness that we ourselves can appreciate God for. Leah is the hated one, she is not as pretty as Rachel, she does not get all the attention she desires but on the other hand, she has been blessed with the fruit of the womb, she is the oldest and that entitles her to get the first service, she has children who can attend to her and she is respected because of the fruits of her womb. When you talk about Rachel, she is the young one therefore she is served last, remember Jacob worked seven years for Rachel but ended up with Leah and therefore Rachel had to wait for 14 years before her dream was fulfilled. She has not been favored to have children and with that she is not getting the same respect as Leah. She doesn’t have children to send, to call her own and be proud of. Looking at what she doesn’t have, I see on the other hand she is beautiful, she is loved more than Leah, she is given the best gifts, she gets the best attention from her husband and yet with all these she is not happy. I saw this with Hannah and Penninah. And because of what Rachel saw in Leah, she envied her, jealousy cropped in and began to cripple her. I don’t know what to say but I think the same must have happened to Leah therefore she tried to have more children to try and cover up the pain inside of her rejection.

You don’t have to agree with me on this but I would say that it is very hard to be happy for someone when you think that what they have should have been with you instead. I also believe that it is very hard to fully appreciate the good things in someone’s life when you don’t see what has been invested in you. Concentrating so much on what someone else has and neglecting to see what you have will always have a tendency of crippling you down stealing contentment in your life. Rachel could have looked at the different areas that she had been favored and say, “Even if I don’t have this and that, God has favored me in other areas where Leah lacks”.

What is my point? Very simple, look at how God designed you to know that you are unique and have no competition. As you might admire what someone else has, remember that they could be admiring what you have that you’ve already dismissed. Understanding what you have will make you appreciate the gifting and the uniqueness in you that in turn someone else’s gifting and uniqueness will not be a threat to you but rather you will rejoice with them over the blessings from the Lord. Instead of envying them and being jealous, pray that God will bless them even more. As you bless them, ask the Lord to bless you too

Genesis 30:1, “…Give me a child, or else I die”. What a tragedy to look to someone to perfect you instead of going back to the One who made you. Rachel made a big mistake by thinking that it might have been Jacob’s fault that she wasn’t having children and this was Jacob’s response, “Am I in the place of God, who has withheld from you the fruit of the womb?” Suppose she blessed Leah and looked to God for her help, I believe God would have remembered her early fruits of her own womb. Blessings Ev

title.rendered: Laboring for Laborers, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“Then he said to his disciples, “The harvest is plentiful but the workers are few. Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field.” (Matt 9:37-38)

It was truly an embarrassing moment when I drove down a one-way street the wrong way. Somehow I failed to see the sign, and therefore the oncoming traffic served as a clear and visible sign that I was heading in the wrong direction, and that I needed to flow with the traffic not against it. Perhaps you’ve not had an experience like this in the natural, but it seems that some believers manifest going the wrong way when it comes to “driving” their prayers up a one-way street against the flow of God’s will. Many are praying for revival, instead of praying in line with God’s will.

In this passage Jesus is looking out among the multitude of people, and compassion begins to well up within Him for they harassed, helpless, confused, aimless, like sheep without a Shepherd. Furthermore they were bullied, oppressed; and in the face of such problems, they are “helpless,” unable to rescue themselves or escape their tormentors. This scene that Jesus looked at broke His heart, as He was burdened for these people. The crux of the problem wasn’t the condition of the shepherd-less sheep, but the scarcity of laborers. Even sheep that have a shepherd have problems, but they have a shepherd present to help them deal with their problems. Christians have the Shepherd in their lives, but the unsaved are like sheep without a Shepherd to save their soul on Judgment Day from Hell.

Jesus’ focus was on the harvest as His metaphor then changed from sheep farming to harvest (v. 37), as Jesus sought to awaken similar compassion in His disciples. He wanted their eyes to see what he saw, for their hearts to feel what he felt, and for their minds to come to the conclusion that His mind came to. Jesus called for a prayer rally on this issue. He wanted harmony on this prayer point (Mt. 18:20), hence all praying for this. This prayer issue needs the resolve of the persistent widow (Luke 8), showing us that we should pray and never give up, especially praying for what Christ told us to pray for. The judge in that story was reluctant to answer the widows persistent request, but God doesn’t deal with us in this manner, but delights to hear His bride, His chosen ones, His body, His church cry day and night unto Him (Luke 18:7). People are God’s love language. How does the church get a heart for the lost, and God’s will (heart) for laborers?

Who do you know that isn’t saved, family member, friend, co-worker, etc…. Now imagine them in the Lake of Fire for all eternity. To think of their fate should cause your heart to feel what Jesus felt looking at those people. He knew that He was the Divine Shepherd they needed and without Him they would perish on the Day of Judgment. Laborers would need to go to them for the crop will be plentiful; many people will be ready to be “reaped” into the kingdom. Luke (10:3) writes of this account but adds that Jesus said, “Go! I am sending you out like lambs among wolves.” He told them not only to pray, but also to GO thus beginning to answer the very prayer they were to pray. “We all, like sheep, have gone astray, each of us has turned to his own way; and the LORD has laid on him the iniquity of us all.” A.W. Pink said, “It is true that [many] are praying for worldwide revival. But it would be more timely, and more scriptural, for prayer to be made to the Lord of the harvest, that He would raise up and trust forth laborers who would fearlessly and faithfully preach those truths which are calculated to bring about a revival.”

Application: Look at the shepherd-less (the unsaved) both those you know and the stranger and see them through Christ’s eyes. By compassion PRAY and GO, they need you NOW! Blessings Pastor Phil

title.rendered: Evangelism is NOT a Spiritual Gift, Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“For the gifts and calling of God are without repentance.” (Romans 11:29)

If one were to peruse the spiritual gifts lists mostly found in 1 Cor. 12, Rom 12, and 1 Pet. 4, one “gift” that will not be listed is that of evangelism. It has been said to be a gift by many, but yet God left if off the list. To me the very essence of evangelism in one word would be the word love. Why the word love, because love is from God. 1 John 4:7 reads, “Dear friends, let us love one another, for love comes from God. Everyone who loves has been born of God and knows God.” We are to love one another, which is the very thing that attracted many in times past to Christianity. I believe it was St. Augustine that said of Christians “Oh, how they love one another,” which was instrumental in bringing him to know Christ. John shows us that the world needs to see us genuinely loving each other as the body of Christ. However, like Emeril, Jesus took it up a notch saying, “You have heard that it has been said, ‘You shall love your neighbor, and hate your enemy.’ But I say to you, Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you;…” (Matt 5).”

We are to love our enemies, and who are they? Ultimately our enemies are the same as God’s enemies which are unbelievers. Isn’t that a bit harsh, to call all non-believers our enemies? Romans 2:5 says, “But because of your stubbornness and your unrepentant heart, you are storing up wrath against yourself for the day of God’s wrath, when His righteous judgment will be revealed. God “will give to each person according to what he has done.” If we love them will we not have compassion on them because we don’t want to see them consumed by God’s great wrath?

Paul reminds us “For as you in times past have not believed God, yet have now obtained mercy through their unbelief: Even so have these also now not believed, that through your mercy they also may obtain mercy. For God has concluded them all in unbelief, that He might have mercy upon all (Romans 11:30-32).”

Many may run to Ephesians 4:11 which speaks of God giving some to be “…evangelists.” However this speaks of a ministry leader in a role to equip the saints, for the work of the ministry, evangelism (soul winning in our context), for the edifying of the body of Christ: “Often Christians pass off their responsibility to reach out to the lost by saying that it’s not their “gifting.” However, there is no such thing as the “gift of evangelism.” That’s like saying, “He has the gift of feeding starving children.” It is not a gift. Rather, he has love enough to take food to the hungry. Another word for evangelism is “love.” The Scriptures here are speaking of the God-given ability of the evangelist to equip the saints for the work of ministry (Ray Comfort).” Evangelism is NOT a gift but is a CALLING for all that call themselves Christians. Will you heed the call, because it is without repentance?

Application: Let compassion, (divine love), swallow all of your excuses and fears for not going out of your way to share your faith with family, friends, enemies, and strangers, ALL of which will spend eternity in the Lake of Fire without the Blood of Christ applied to their sins. Blessings Pastor Phil

title.rendered: The Leader’s Covering – Part 3, By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“Take the other ram, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on its head. Slaughter it, take some of its blood and put it on the lobes of the right ears of Aaron and his sons, on the thumbs of their right hands, and on the big toes of their right feet… (Exodus 29:19-20)

Applying the blood to the ear, was about hearing only God’s Word, while applying it to the thumb was about rightly serving God and God’s people. Lastly, but equally important is the application of the blood covering to the “big toes of their right feet,” so that the sanctified walk of the priests would be examples to the people. What priest walked here on earth in perfect righteousness? Hebrews tells us, “Such a high priest [Jesus] meets our need—one who is holy, blameless, pure, set apart from sinners, exalted above the heavens (7:26). A priest offers sacrifice on behalf of the people, and Jesus offered His very life to be the sacrifice as well. The many former OT priests died, ‘But this man [Jesus] because He continues ever, has an unchangeable priesthood… “Who needs not daily, as those high priests to offer sacrifice, first for his own sins, and then for the people’s: for this he did once, when he offered up himself (5:10; 7:24,27).” Jesus didn’t only offer the sacrifice as the priest, He was the sacrifice once and for all which is why he said, “It is finished on the cross.”

Jesus walked in righteousness as a priest proclaiming that He Himself came for this very purpose as He said, “For the Son of Man came to seek and to save what was lost.” If we are to walk in righteousness the blood of Christ needs to be applied to our big toe and the rest of our foot because God tells us, “How beautiful are the feet of those who bring good news!” If we truly walk in righteousness our feet will be carrying us to preach the good news.” “But now a righteousness from God, apart from law, has been made known, to which the Law and the Prophets testify. This righteousness from God comes through faith in Jesus Christ to all who believe. There is no difference…” The Law and the prophets walked in righteousness to bring spoken testimony and point to Christ. Only faith in Christ can bring about God’s righteousness. The Law doesn’t make us righteous, it doesn’t help us, and rather it leaves us helpless with the need to throw ourselves at the feet of the Savior. After now being born again by the Holy Spirit, and realizing that “…you are a chosen people, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people belonging to God…1 Peter 2:9, we need to present our lives as living sacrifices to reach the lost for Christ. The lost need desperately to have the blood of the Savior applied to their sins to be redeemed from the curse of the Law of sin and death. God has left that mission to you and me to do. “We are therefore Christ’s ambassadors, as though God were making his appeal through us (2 Cor. 5:20).” “To them God has chosen to make known among the Gentiles the glorious riches of this mystery, which is Christ in you, the hope of glory (Col 1:27).”

Application: Do you have the blood of Christ applied to your toe, and are your feet mobilized to go seek and save the lost. Are your feet fitted with the readiness that comes from the gospel of peace (Eph 6:15)? If you want to be used by God then move those feet that God gave you for Him and His glory. “Satan prefers 1,000,000 choir members or pew-warmers to one Christian who is prepared to obey the command to preach the Gospel (Ray Comfort)” Many believers have their feet stuck it seems when it’s time for obeying our mission to seek and save the lost because of all the excuses and a lack of zeal and urgency. To bring common ground many have said “he puts his pants on one leg at a time. However there is one group, they put their pants on two legs at a time. Firefighters live with a sense of urgency, because they must respond to the alarm that they must GO or people will die. How much more truthful can that reality be for the Christians. You’re either going or staying, but only is done in obedience and you know which that is. Now GO!, blessings Pastor Phil
